REC.r_id_disclaimer: ResearcherID data provided by Clarivate Analytics

grant.grant_agency: National Important Basic Research Project of China

abstract_text.p: Whether radar meteor echoes occur at high altitudes (above similar to 130 km) in the Earth's atmosphere is a long-standing question within the meteor radar community. Using observations from the Sanya VHF coherent radar interferometer during 11 July to 10 August 2013, we have found a new class of range-spread high-altitude meteor trail echoes (HAMEs), some of which appeared at similar to 170 km altitude lasting more than 10 s. A statistical analysis on the local time dependence of the identified HAME events shows a maximum around 00-04 LT. The results imply that there could be much more meteor mass input due to meteoroid sputtering at high altitudes in the Earth's atmosphere than previously thought.
